ggasym 0.0.0.9000

Complete the \(n \times n\) matrix and make asymmetric

prepare_asymmetric_tibble.Rd

This function is designed to make the "other half" of the \(n \times n\) matrix. It copies the matrix, reversing .x and .y, followed by only keeping the top-left (.tl) and bottom-right (br) values in the correct rows.

prepare_asymmetric_tibble(.data, .x, .y, .tl, .br)

Arguments

.data

a tibble with at least four columns for the x and y-axes (.x and .y) and the top-left and bottom-right values (.tl and .br)
.x, .y

x and y-axes column names
.tl, .br

top-left and bottom right column names

Examples

library(tibble)

tib <- tibble(a = LETTERS[1:5],
              b = LETTERS[10:14],
              val_1 = c(0.70, 0.05, 0.14, 0.60, 0.83),
              val_2 = c(0.78, 0.25, 0.74, 0.26, 0.16))

tib
#> # A tibble: 5 x 4
#>   a     b     val_1 val_2
#>   <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 A     J      0.7   0.78
#> 2 B     K      0.05  0.25
#> 3 C     L      0.14  0.74
#> 4 D     M      0.6   0.26
#> 5 E     N      0.83  0.16

prepare_asymmetric_tibble(tib, a, b, val_1, val_2)
#> # A tibble: 10 x 4
#>    a     b     val_1 val_2
#>    <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 A     J      0.7  NA   
#>  2 B     K      0.05 NA   
#>  3 C     L      0.14 NA   
#>  4 D     M      0.6  NA   
#>  5 E     N      0.83 NA   
#>  6 J     A     NA     0.78
#>  7 K     B     NA     0.25
#>  8 L     C     NA     0.74
#>  9 M     D     NA     0.26
#> 10 N     E     NA     0.16
